description: From Middle English celebraten, from Latin celebratus, past pariticiple of celebrō (“frequent, go to in great numbers, celebrate, honor, praise”), from celeber (“frequented, populous”). Displaced native Old English fæġnian.

verbs.description: celebrate (third-person singular simple present celebrates, present participle celebrating, simple past and past participle celebrated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To extol or honour in a solemn manner.
examples: to celebrate the name of the Most High

entries.meaning: (transitive) To honour by rites, by ceremonies of joy and respect, or by refraining from ordinary business; to observe duly.
(intransitive) To engage in joyful activity in appreciation of an event.
examples: I was promoted today at work—let’s celebrate!

entries.meaning: (transitive) To perform or participate in, as a sacrament or solemn rite; to perform with appropriate rites.
